content:
=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Based on the rules provided, here’s an overall breakdown of what's going on in the game:

1. Game Genre and Setting
 • It’s a tile‐based, action-puzzle/platformer reminiscent of classics like Spelunky or Boulder Dash. 
 • The game board is laid out as a grid with various kinds of sprites (walls, dirt, and special items) that define a treacherous level full of obstacles, enemies, and resources.

2. Game Mechanics
 • Movement and Interaction: You control an avatar that can move, possibly shoot or swing a sword, and interact with both static and moving objects.
 • Resources and Obstacles: 
  – Diamonds are scattered around as primary resources. Picking them up increases your score.
  – Dirt, walls, and boulders form the level’s terrain. Boulders move (or fall) slowly and can “kill” the avatar if hit from a certain angle.
 • Enemies: There are several enemy types (random NPCs, crabs, and butterflies). Their behavior is partly random, and some interact with each other—for example, crabs can kill butterflies, and interestingly butterflies can transform crabs into diamonds, adding a twist to enemy encounters.
 • Special Tools: 
  – The sword appears to be limited (only one on the level at a time) and is used to eliminate certain sprites; for instance, using a sword against dirt via the set interaction “dirt avatar sword > killSprite” may be one way to clear paths.

3. Objective and Win/Loss Conditions
 • Primary Objective: Navigate the level to collect diamonds. In fact, the exit door’s interaction (“exitdoor avatar > killIfOtherHasMore resource=diamond limit=9”) suggests that you need to gather at least 10 diamonds before you can successfully “use” the exit door.
 • Winning: The game is won when the exitdoor sprite is removed (or “killed”) from the level—this happens when you successfully interact with it while meeting the diamond requirement.
 • Losing: You lose if your avatar is eliminated (“SpriteCounter stype=avatar limit=0 win=False”).

4. Overall Strategy
 • Explore Cautiously: Survey the level and plan your moves. The layout is filled with hazards (moving boulders, enemy patterns) and obstacles (walls, dirt) that require careful navigation.
 • Diamond Collection: Focus on collecting diamonds to reach the threshold needed to exit. Identify safe routes and consider how to use enemy interactions (for example, letting butterflies convert crabs into diamonds) to boost your resource count.
 • Use the Sword Wisely: Since the sword is limited, use it sparingly to clear dirt (or possibly other obstacles) without endangering yourself.
 • Manage Enemies and Hazards: Keep an eye on moving boulders and enemy placements. Avoid getting crushed by boulders unless you have a clear advantage (e.g., jumping on them from above might help mitigate their danger according to the rules) and plan encounters with enemies to minimize unwanted score penalties.
 • Exit at the Right Time: Only approach the exit door after ensuring you have collected enough diamonds. Rushing to the door without the necessary resources could be fatal.

In summary, you’re playing a dynamic platformer where exploration, resource collection, and clever manipulation of interactions (between enemies and items) are key. Balance risk and reward: clear obstacles and enemies with your sword and smart moves, collect enough diamonds to “unlock” the exit door, and navigate past hazards to complete each level.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game. 

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background dirt -> '.'
background -> '-'
background exitdoor -> 'e'
background boulder -> 'o'
background diamond -> 'x'
background crab -> 'c'
background butterfly -> 'b'
boulder -> '@'
butterfly -> '#'
crab -> '$'
diamond -> '%'
dirt -> '&'
exitdoor -> '*'
wall -> 'b'

I'm moving down from row6, col11 into an open space at row7, col11 to explore a safer area and approach potential diamond paths.
